items.title: If Gemini really wants to be everywhere, it should start with these 6 blind spots
items.summary: Gemini is everywhere â€” except where I actually want it.
items.body: Like it or not, AI is now an inseparable part of our digital lives . It has come to a point where not using it can make you feel like youâ€™re being left behind â€” whether itâ€™s about automating small tasks or letting AI â€œprofessionally writeâ€ your emails before you hit send. Gemini is expanding its presence across Android phones and the apps within, aiming to be the single assistant to rule them all. It can talk to you in natural language, help you take actions, and sometimes even act on your behalf. I wasnâ€™t too fond of this AI invasion over the processes Iâ€™d followed for years, but now Iâ€™ve grown used to it â€” so much so that I actually want Gemini in more places. And here they are.

items.title: O'Sullivan turns on style to avoid first-round exit
items.summary: Ronnie O'Sullivan makes four centuries in the final five frames to beat world number 76 Allan Taylor 6-5 at the International Championship in China.

items.title: Heads-up: A 10,000mAh Qi2 power bank will only charge your Pixel 10 once
items.summary: Don't trust the battery capacity you see on the main packaging. You're never getting that.
items.body: Credit: Rita El Khoury / Android Authority If youâ€™ve bought a Google Pixel 10 series phone , odds are youâ€™ve been looking at compatible Qi2 and Qi2 25W accessories and wondering what to pick up. A desk charger like the Pixelsnap Charger with Stand , a magnetic wallet, a MagSafe-compatible tripod â€” all of these are good ideas. But the one accessory I was personally looking forward to the most is a Qi2 power bank. Just snap it on the back of my phone and get a relatively fast charge without any wires or tangles. I ended up with several of these portable batteries to test out, and while I do appreciate their convenience, one thing stood out in all of my tests: You should really be wary of the batteryâ€™s capacity. 10,000mAh wonâ€™t be enough to charge your ~5,000mAh Pixel 10, 10 Pro, or 10 Pro XL more than once.

items.title: Griffin hopes he can be Wales' magic number three
items.summary: Bath prop Archie Griffin is hoping to nail down the problem Wales number three jersey this autumn.

items.title: Mark your calendars: Samsung will reportedly â€˜Unpackâ€™ the Galaxy S26 series on this date!
items.summary: It looks like we'll be waiting till late February for the new flagships.
items.body: TL;DR The launch date for the Galaxy S26 series has leaked. Samsung is now expected to launch its 2026 flagships at Unpacked in San Francisco on February 25. The leaked information aligns with earlier reports of a delayed launch for the series. A new report from Korean outlet Money Today (via Jukan on X ) claims that Samsung will launch the Galaxy S26 series at an Unpacked event in San Francisco on February 25, 2026. The company has yet to officially confirm the date, but industry sources cited by the publication indicate that Samsung has begun preparations for the launch. If the leaked Galaxy S26 launch date is accurate, this would mark Samsungâ€™s first San Francisco-based Galaxy S event since the launch of the Galaxy S23 series in 2023.

items.title: 5 smartwatches you should buy instead of the Google Pixel Watch 4
items.summary: The Pixel Watch 4 is outstanding, but so are these alternatives.
items.body: The Google Pixel Watch 4 is an outstanding smartwatch. In fact, you could argue that itâ€™s the best Wear OS watch released this year. With its new Acuta 360 display, longer battery life, improved repairability, and excellent Gemini integration, itâ€™s about as complete a package as you could ask for. Although we strongly recommend buying the Pixel Watch 4, itâ€™s worth reminding that it isnâ€™t your only option if youâ€™re currently smartwatch shopping. In fact, there are still a lot of other great watches you should consider.

items.title: I didnâ€™t care about my phoneâ€™s camera specs, but 5 things changed that
items.summary: I wasn't always a smartphone camera snob.
items.body: There are certain smartphone features I never compromise on , and one of these is specific camera criteria. However, things werenâ€™t always this way, and there was a time when I focused more on other aspects â€” such as whether I liked the phoneâ€™s design or the brand itself. So what changed? Here are a few of the things that made me start caring more about my smartphone camera than I used to.

items.title: The Pixel 10 Proâ€™s new voice typing is wild, and itâ€™s changed how I use my phone
items.summary: No hands necessary.
items.body: I started using Googleâ€™s Gboard keyboard long before I made the switch to Android. Even as a third-party keyboard on an iPhone , I found it better than the native iOS typing experience. With Gboard on Android â€” and more specifically on its own Pixel devices â€” Google has consistently added new features and to this day, I consider it best in class (donâ€™t ask me to use an iOS keyboard, please). The single most impressive feature of Gboard, however, doesnâ€™t involve tapping on the keys. Instead, I opt for voice typing whenever possible, and Gboardâ€™s voice typing has been good for so long that itâ€™s easy to take for granted. But Google just one-upped itself in a major way with a brand new voice typing command that absolutely blew my mind: you can now edit your text with the sound of your voice, and it works incredibly well. From voice typing novice to Gboard power user

items.title: England win thriller to clinch Wheelchair Ashes
items.summary: Joe Coyd scores a try two minutes from time as England produce a stunning fightback to beat Australia in the final Test and win the Wheelchair Rugby League Ashes.

items.title: The former England masterminds looking to build a 'superpower'
items.summary: When something works successfully, it makes sense to try it again. That's what Kay Cossington and Anja van Ginhoven are doing.

items.title: How Colts went from outsiders to unstoppable
items.summary: Phoebe Schecter explains how the Indianapolis Colts went from one of the NFL's lowest ranked teams to this season's pacesetters - and why they could go all the way.

items.title: Dodgers seal back-to-back World Series titles
items.summary: The Los Angeles Dodgers become the first team for 25 years to win back-to-back World Series after overcoming the Toronto Blue Jays in the deciding seventh game.

items.title: Are Wales players getting enough game time?
items.summary: Wales head coach Sean Lynn knows a lack of match minutes has become a major factor in the national team's recent demise.

items.title: Did Spurs players refuse to applaud fans after Chelsea defeat?
items.summary: Match of the Day's Gabby Logan, Alan Shearer and Ashley Williams dissect the reaction of Tottenham's Djed Spence and Micky van de Ven after their defeat by Chelsea.

items.title: The Amad conundrum that Man Utd need to solve
items.summary: Match of the Day's Ashley Williams and Alan Shearer look at the performance of Manchester United's Amad Diallo and the challenge of fitting him into Ruben Amorim's system.

items.title: Barrett 'gutted' for Beirne after controversial red
items.summary: New Zealand's Beauden Barrett says he is "gutted" for Tadhg Beirne after the Irish second row was sent off early in Saturday's 26-13 defeat in Chicago.

items.title: Calafiori, Timber and Rice 'integral' to Arsenal success - analysis
items.summary: Match of the Day pundits Alan Shearer and Ashley Williams discuss what makes Riccardo Calafiori, Jurrien Timber and Declan Rice so integral to the success of Arsenal so far.

items.title: Bellingham and Mbappe shine as Real Madrid thrash Valencia
items.summary: Jude Bellingham scores and Kylian Mbappe nets twice as Real Madrid open up a seven-point lead in La Liga with a comfortable win over Valencia at Santiago Bernabeu.

items.title: Salah shines as Slot & Liverpool get fans' backing
items.summary: When Liverpool needed a boost, the Anfield crowd motivated the Reds to a vital win - with Mohamed Salah returning to form.

items.title: Underwhelming Buatsi outpoints Parker in Manchester
items.summary: Joshua Buatsi made a winning yet underwhelming start as a Queensberry fighter with a close points victory over Zach Parker.

items.title: Villa & Man Utd want Endrick - Sunday's gossip
items.summary: Aston Villa, Manchester United and Lyon are keen on Real Madrid striker Endrick, Napoli want Manchester United's Kobbie Mainoo in January and N'Golo Kante could make return to France, plus more.

items.title: Mullins wins at Breeders' Cup with Ethical Diamond
items.summary: Ethical Diamond wins the Breeders' Cup Turf with a stunning late run in a course record for Grand National-winning trainer Willie Mullins.

items.title: Fans booing and players snubbing the manager - an 'abject' day for Spurs
items.summary: Despite being third in the table and unbeaten in the Champions League, all is not rosy at Tottenham after Chelsea inflict another home defeat.

items.title: Liverpool showed character to beat Villa - Slot
items.summary: Liverpool boss Arne Slot says his side showed great character as they beat Aston Villa 2-0 to end their Premier League losing run.

items.title: Leaders Hearts in 'dreamland' but might it get even better?
items.summary: Chief executive Andrew McKinlay thinks Hearts are destined to eventually win the Scottish title, but could it be this season?

items.title: Palace end winless run with victory over in-form Brentford
items.summary: Crystal Palace end a three-match winless run in the Premier League with victory over in-form Brentford at Selhurst Park.

items.title: Gomez shines as Brighton claim comfortable win over Leeds
items.summary: Diego Gomez nets twice and Danny Welbeck scores for third successive league game as Brighton comfortably beat Leeds to move into the top-half of the Premier League table.

items.title: Fulham condemn 10-man Wolves to eighth defeat of season
items.summary: Wolves' season continues to spiral after Fulham condemn them to another damaging defeat to keep them winless and bottom of the Premier League.

items.title: Arsenal go seven points clear with win over Burnley
items.summary: Premier League leaders Arsenal continue their impressive start to the season with a comfortable win at Burnley to make it nine consecutive victories in all competitions.

items.title: Late Amad volley earns Man Utd point in thriller at Forest
items.summary: Amad Diallo lashes home a thunderous 81st-minute volley to earn Manchester United a point in a thrilling Premier League encounter with Nottingham Forest at the City Ground.

items.title: Pedro goal gives Chelsea deserved win over lacklustre Tottenham
items.summary: Joao Pedro ends his 10-game goal drought to give Chelsea a deserved victory as Tottenham were booed off after another dismal home performance.

items.title: Salah scores as Liverpool end losing streak with win over Villa
items.summary: Mohamed Salah scores his 250th Liverpool goal as the Reds end their four-game Premier League losing streak with victory over Aston Villa.

items.title: 'I can't see a weakness' - is this Arsenal's time for a title?
items.summary: It is, of course, still early days but could this be Arsenal's time to win the Premier League? BBC Sport takes a look at why the Gunners' title charge is already looking strong.

items.title: Macclesfield overpower Totton in nine-goal tie
items.summary: Danny Elliott scored a first-half hat-trick for Macclesfield to help his side to a 6-3 victory against AFC Totton.

items.title: Faith in style pays off for St Mirren on All Saints Day
items.summary: Stephen Robinson might bridle at his team's reputation for physicality, but his players have delivered a League Cup final place.

items.title: England's Ashes hopes end with 'reality check'
items.summary: England have been handed a "good reality check" in seeing their Rugby League Ashes hopes ended by Australia, says captain George Williams.

items.title: Bompastor backs 'class' Hampton after Earps comments
items.summary: Chelsea manager Sonia Bompastor says goalkeeper Hannah Hampton has shown "class" in response to Mary Earps' comments about her.

items.title: Non-league Brackley Town beat Notts County on penalties
items.summary: Brackley Town win 4-3 on penalties against Notts County in the first round of the FA Cup.

items.title: Earl and Pollock make case for backline experiment
items.summary: England back rows Ben Earl and Henry Pollock show the pace to back Steve Borthwick's bold tactical plan.

items.title: Gerrard came 'very close' to Rangers return
items.summary: Steven Gerrard reveals he was "very close" to returning to Rangers as manager but ultimately turned down the role because things were "not perfect".

items.title: 'A different feeling' - have Man Utd shown mentality shift?
items.summary: Ruben Amorim believes in previous seasons, Manchester United would not have come back to draw with Nottingham Forest.

items.title: FA Cup round-up: Gateshead and Carlisle provide first-round shocks
items.summary: Carlisle United and Gateshead provide the biggest shocks of the FA Cup first round with away wins over EFL opponents Reading and AFC Wimbledon.

items.title: Does 'timeless wonder' Welbeck deserve England recall?
items.summary: Danny Welbeck last played for England in 2018 but will his recent form at Brighton be enough to encourage Thomas Tuchel to select him for this month's World Cup qualifiers?

items.title: Dyche wants VAR to rule on corners after 'farcical' decisions
items.summary: Nottingham Forest manager Sean Dyche calls for VAR to overrule wrongly awarded corners after a second decision goes against his side.

items.summary: Celtic and Rangers meet in Sunday's Premier Sports Cup semi-final after a period of internal strive for both sides of the Glasgow divide, writes Tom English.

items.title: 'Absolutely incredible' goal sends Buxton into second round
items.summary: Connor Kirby scores an "absolute worldie" in extra time as Buxton beat Chatham Town 2-1 in the FA Cup first round.

items.title: Ruthless Sinner beats Zverev to reach Paris final
items.summary: A ruthless Jannik Sinner takes apart Alexander Zverev to reach the Paris Masters final and move within one win of regaining the world number one ranking.

items.title: Arteta lauds 'exceptional'  Arsenal defence in win at Burnley
items.summary: Arsenal boss Mikel Arteta is full of praise for his side's defensive display in their 2-0 win against Burnley at Turf Moor.

items.title: Man City secure sixth successive win despite West Ham battle
items.summary: Aoba Fujino's goal is enough to secure a Manchester City win, despite bottom-of-the-table West Ham United fighting hard to create chances.

items.title: Chelsea continue unbeaten start with win over London City
items.summary: Chelsea maintain their unbeaten start in the Women's Super League with a 2-0 victory over London City Lionesses with an early goal from summer signing Ellie Carpenter and substitute Sam Kerr scoring late on.

items.title: Barnsley score 91st-minute winner to beat York City
items.summary: Marc Roberts scores in the 91st minute for Barnsley to earn a 3-2 win against York City in the first round of the FA Cup.

items.title: Swiatek and Rybakina earn dominant WTA Finals wins
items.summary: Iga Swiatek and Elena Rybakina produce statement opening victories on the first day of the WTA Finals in Riyadh.

items.title: Australia beat determined England to clinch Ashes
items.summary: Australia edge a much-improved England to win the second Test 14-4 at the Hill Dickinson Stadium to clinch a 14th consecutive Ashes series triumph.

items.title: Android Auto is borrowing a key new Apple CarPlay feature
items.summary: This week, we discuss why Google is bringing widgets to Android Auto and AOD app integration to Android 17.
items.body: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rib6xSD7Ilk This week, Mishaal Rahman and C. Scott Brown discuss the upcoming addition of home screen widgets to Android Auto, a new â€œMin Modeâ€ in Android 17 that could revolutionize the always-on display for apps like Google Maps, and the disappointing gaming performance of the Pixel 10. The Authority Insights Podcast is a new weekly show from the Android Authority team hosted by Mishaal Rahman and C. Scott Brown. In each episode, weâ€™ll break down the latest exclusive reports, app teardowns, and leaks from the Android Authority team.

items.title: The Android IRS: How Google once tried to tax battery-sucking background apps
items.summary: Android almost had its own IRS that would audit apps for their battery usage. Hereâ€™s how it wouldâ€™ve worked.
items.body: There are three things that are certain in life: death, taxes, and Google restricting background work. With every new Android release, Google seemingly further restricts what apps running in the background can do. This is understandable because battery power is a finite commodity on Android phones , so allowing apps to do whatever they want whenever they want would be detrimental to battery life. To prevent rogue applications from draining your phoneâ€™s battery , the Android OS implements a number of battery management tactics to control when apps can run and how long they can run. Apps that need to perform critical, real-time tasks like downloading a file, tracking a run, or playing music can create a foreground service, but in order to do so, they must show a notification so users are aware. Instead of creating a foreground service, Google recommends most developers use APIs like JobScheduler and AlarmManager (or a higher-level wrapper, like WorkManager) to queue tasks in the background.

items.title: Why England fans should not lose Ashes hope despite ODI series defeat
items.summary: England's batting was concerning in their 3-0 ODI series defeat by New Zealand but it does not mean fans should give up Ashes hope, writes Matthew Henry.

items.title: Verizon is in crisis: Hereâ€™s what its new CEO must do to turn things around
items.summary: Verizon promises big changes, but does it actually have a plan?
items.body: Recently, I reported that AT&T, T-Mobile, and Verizon had all released their Q3 2025 financial results. Verizonâ€™s rivals are doing well, but Big Red finds itself in a much less rosy position. While it did manage to add more than 40,000 new subscribers this quarter, those gains came entirely from its prepaid and business divisions. Its postpaid phone service actually lost 7,000 subscribers during this period. With T-Mobile edging ever closer to surpassing Verizonâ€™s total subscriber count, itâ€™s clear big changes are needed if Verizon wants to turn this ship around. Verizonâ€™s new CEO, Dan Schulman, insists the company is working hard to do just that, and that it will â€œno longer be the hunting ground for competitors looking to gain shareâ€.

items.title: The Pixel 10 Pro is the Pixel Iâ€™ve always wanted Google to make
items.summary: The Pixel 10 Pro atones for the sins of Pixels' past to become my ideal smartphone.
items.body: I find it hard to believe weâ€™ve had ten generations of Pixel already. The event for the original Pixel in October 2016 is still vivid in my mind â€” Iâ€™d never been as excited for a phone as I was in that moment, and I havenâ€™t felt that excitement since, either. As enamored by the Pixel as I was, I stopped using Pixels for over six years, and with good reason. The Pixel 10 Pro , though, is the phone Iâ€™ve been waiting for Google to make. What went wrong If I used to be so excited about the Pixel, you may wonder when and why that stopped. Well, by the time the Pixel 3 arrived, the honeymoon period had ended. My time with the early Pixels was plagued with defective phones and issues Iâ€™d grown tired of. My Pixel XL, 2 XL, and 3 XL all had to be swapped on warranty at least three times, and the Pixel 3 XL made things worse by being a frustrating device even when it was working as intended.

items.title: Iâ€™m my familyâ€™s tech expert, and this is the cheap Android phone I told my mom to buy
items.summary: ...and what she actually bought instead.
items.body: Whether you canâ€™t wait to let go of your current Android phone or canâ€™t imagine living without it, there will come a time when youâ€™ll have to upgrade. I reluctantly faced this fact earlier this year when my beloved six-year-old phone finally showed signs of fatigue. More recently, my mom had to deal with the same problem. Sheâ€™s been using the same budget Android 10 phone for nearly four years now, a device that still works but no longer runs the apps she needs. So, naturally, it was time for a newer device with swifter hardware and fresher software.

items.title: 5 of the best new Android apps you need to try this November
items.summary: Here are the hot new Android wares to try in the month ahead.
items.body: Keeping up with the latest and greatest apps and games is a difficult task, but Iâ€™m here to help. Each month, I detail a list of the best new Android apps and games, and the November edition is packed with a wide range of options for all. Letâ€™s jump right in. Here are the best new Android apps and games you should try in November 2025.

items.title: Is your Pixel getting Googleâ€™s surprise update? Hereâ€™s every supported phone
items.summary: It's Pixel update time ... again!
items.body: One of the best things about having a Pixel phone is being first in line for software updates. Google typically releases one update per month for Pixels, with the October 2025 update having arrived on October 8. But on October 30, Google released a second October update â€” seemingly out of nowhere. The company hasnâ€™t said what it fixes or changes, but weâ€™ll certainly never complain about two software updates in one month.

items.title: How new MLS franchise San Diego are creating history

items.title: Hereâ€™s how you can score a Mint Mobile plan for just $10 per month
items.summary: We've got a limited-time promo code that can save you 30% on the already cheap 12-month plans.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority Mint Mobile has made a name for itself as one of the most recognizable prepaid carriers in the US, thanks in part to Ryan Reynoldsâ€™ ads and its simple approach to mobile plans. It runs on the T-Mobile network, but as an MVNO, it already undercuts the big three networks by a wide margin. However, a new offer that you wonâ€™t see advertised on the site makes its 12-month plans even cheaper. For a limited time, new customers can get 30% off all 12-month fixed-data plans using the code YEAROFMINT . That drops the 5GB plan from $15 to $10.50 per month, paid upfront for the year. The code should automatically apply if you use this link or widget below, but itâ€™s worth noting down just in case.

items.title: Luton beat Forest Green in rollercoaster seven-goal tie
items.summary: Luton Town reach the FA Cup second round with an injury-time winner after Forest Green Rovers stage a remarkable comeback from three goals down in a thrilling first-round encounter.

items.title: YouTube execs flat-out deny claims Biden admin pushed for censorship
items.summary: The testimony flies in the face of Alphabet's September letter to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
items.body: TL;DR Back in September, Alphabet blamed YouTube censorship policies on pressure from the Biden administration. Numerous YouTube executives have given testimony that directly rebuts that claim. Now Committee on the Judiciary ranking member Jamie Raskin is demanding answers. The past ten months have got to be the start of one of the most embarrassing years for tech heavyweights in recent memory. One after the other, firms like Apple, Meta, NVIDIA, Microsoft, Amazon, and of course, Google, have been prostrating themselves before a government administration theyâ€™d previously butted heads with . But in 2025, acquiescence is the name of the game, and rather than bracing for another four years of conflict, theyâ€™ve instead been kissing the ring. A few weeks back, that extended to YouTube performing a massive about-face on the necessary steps it had taken to ban some of the worst voices on its platform , spreading lies, hate, and disinformation â€” instead opening the door to restore their access. That move was telegraphed in late September when Alphabet legal counsel submitted a letter to the House Committee on the Judiciary, blaming COVID-era YouTube moderation policies on pressure the coâ€¦

items.title: Augsburg v Dortmund halted after fireworks land on pitch
items.summary: The Bundesliga match between Augsburg and Borussia Dortmund is halted after spectators send fireworks onto the pitch.

items.title: Google just opened its AI mood-boarding tool to most of the world
items.summary: The creative AI-playground enters global rollout, hinting at how Google sees "idea making" evolving.
items.body: TL;DR Mixboard, Googleâ€™s experimental AI canvas for images and text, is now expanding to over 180 additional countries. Boards are now up to four times larger, providing users with more space to brainstorm, sketch, and create visuals. Itâ€™s still an early-stage Google Labs tool, but it offers an easy way to explore AI-assisted creativity. Google first introduced Mixboard back in September: an AI-powered image-and-text canvas where you can upload photos, drop in text, and tap Googleâ€™s models, including Nano Banana , to brainstorm, generate visuals, or refine ideas. Now Google shares that this experimental tool is rolling out to 180+ additional countries. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Samsung is working on a follow-up to its best mid-ranger of 2025
items.summary: The Samsung Galaxy A57 is in development.
items.body: TL;DR The Samsung Galaxy A57â€™s model number has reportedly been spotted on Samsungâ€™s firmware test servers. That would confirm that the unannounced phone is currently in development. This yearâ€™s Galaxy A56 came to the US months after international release. We have no release timeline for the A57. Samsungâ€™s Galaxy A56 is a capable mid-ranger that made its way to the US months after its international release . We liked it quite a bit â€” in fact, our own Zac Kew-Denniss said itâ€™s a better value than the Galaxy S25 . Now, thereâ€™s apparent confirmation that the A56â€™s sequel is currently in development. User Koram_Akhilesh posted screenshots on Twitter (spotted by SamMobile ) purportedly showing that the Galaxy A57â€™s firmware has been found on Samsungâ€™s test servers, identified by model number SM-A576B.

items.title: Poll: What channels would make you cancel YouTube TV if they disappeared?
items.summary: Six media companies control over 50 of the channels you watch on YouTube TV.
items.body: YouTube TV is the market leader in live TV streaming, with the most popular, and one of the most expensive , subscription services. The platform is estimated to have more than 10 million subscribers, and costs $83 per month. The high price understandably results in consumer frustration when major channels disappear from YouTube TV during negotiations â€” something that has already happened multiple times in 2025. This time, YouTube TV fans are noticing that all Disney content is unavailable as of October 30 , when their contract expired. A whopping 21 channels immediately disappeared from the platform, including big names like ABC, ESPN, and National Geographic. You might not know that most of your favorite channels are consolidated under just a few media companies. That means when YouTube TV fails to reach a deal with the largest brands, an entire chunk of channels go dark.

items.title: Boom or bubble? Google wants to help you beat the market
items.summary: A little Google assistance might be just what your portfolio needs.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR Google Finance beta adds live earnings calls, transcripts, and AI summaries. You can browse an earnings calendar and compare company results in real time. Itâ€™s available now in the US as part of Googleâ€™s wider Finance revamp. The US stock market is flying high right now, but some experts are ringing alarm bells. NVIDIA and other AI giants continue to smash records, while nervous analysts warn that all the hype could come crashing down. If youâ€™re trying to stay one step ahead of the next swing in sentiment, Googleâ€™s latest tool might come in handy. The company has added a new earnings experience to the Google Finance beta, bringing live audio streams, instant transcripts, and AI-powered summaries that explain the key takeaways from company results. Itâ€™s the latest addition to the redesigned Finance page that Google began testing in August.

items.title: PSA: Donâ€™t toss away your old Nest Thermostat yet â€” it just got thrown a lifeline
items.summary: Your first/second-gen Nest Learning Thermostat still has life.
items.body: TL;DR Earlier this year, Google announced it would end support for the first- and second-generation Nest Learning Thermostat on October 25, 2025. These thermostats can still be used, but you can no longer control them remotely, receive notifications, check the status in the Nest or Home app, or change settings from a mobile device. One Reddit user says theyâ€™re building a website/local server to restore these functions, and they may even build a mobile app if thereâ€™s enough traction. One of the biggest flaws with the concept of smart homes is planned obsolescence. Thatâ€™s exactly what happened to the first- and second-generation Nest Learning Thermostat last week. But donâ€™t throw your thermostat away just yet. It can still be used, and it may not stay dumb for long. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Did you watch YouTube growing up? You may be entitled to compensation
items.summary: If you were 13 or younger and watched YouTube between 2013 and 2020, you just might have a few bucks coming your way.
items.body: TL;DR A 2019 class-action suit against Google and YouTube was settled for $30 million. The suit accused Google and YouTube of collecting identifying information about minors without parental consent. Affected users are now able to file claims to potentially receive a portion of the $30 million settlement. Kids watch a lot of YouTube. Googleâ€™s keenly aware of that: It offers a version of the YouTube app thatâ€™s explicitly made for childrenâ€™s content in YouTube Kids, and earlier this year, rolled out a controversial AI-based age estimation system to automatically flag accounts that may be used by minors. These measures are meant in part to help Google avoid legal trouble â€” like a 2019 class-action suit filed in California accusing Google and YouTube of violating privacy laws by collecting information about minors for the purposes of advertising. The suit was eventually settled for a sum of $30 million, and now, according to Top Class Actions , affected users are able to submit claims to get a cut of that settlement.

items.title: Goveeâ€™s colorful new smart plug could replace your power strip and lamp
items.summary: A compact 8-in-1 power hub with built-in lighting for your smart home.
items.body: Credit: Amazon TL;DR Govee just launched its new Smart Plug Outlet Extender, which combines six outlets, two USB ports, and an RGB night light in one wall-mounted hub. Two smart outlets can be controlled via app or voice, while the rest remain always on. The device is priced at $36.99 with a 5% coupon currently available on Amazon. Goveeâ€™s latest smart home gadget is a little more colorful than most power strips. The company has launched the new Goveelife Smart Plug Outlet Extender, a compact hub that combines six outlets, two USB ports , and an integrated RGB night light in a single wall-mounted unit. Itâ€™s now available to buy in the US for $36.99. The device went on preorder earlier in the week and is now listed on Amazon, where a 5% coupon brings the price down to roughly $35. The 8-in-1 extender includes two app-controlled smart outlets on the front, while the four always-on outlets sit along the sides â€” giving you three plug-in surfaces in total. Thereâ€™s also a USB-C and a USB-A port. Govee says the sockets are spaced to fit bulkier adapters without blocking each other, which is a common complaint associated with poorly designed power strips.

items.title: Leaked Samsung Pass build adds passport, ID storage, and more
items.summary: Itâ€™s not Wallet yet, but itâ€™s definitely acting like one.
items.body: Credit: Joe Hindy / Android Authority TL;DR A leaked Samsung Pass APK suggests upcoming support for securely storing passports, ID cards, driverâ€™s licenses, banking invoices, and more. However, the build currently suffers from bugs such as missing password access and Samsung Cloud sync. The leak hints that Samsung may fold deeper ID storage into Wallet as it continues shifting Pass toward a unified, Knox-secured identity hub. Samsung Pass, the companyâ€™s biometric vault for passwords and personal data, may be getting a major expansion. Screenshots of a leaked APK were shared by GalaxyTechie on X, hinting that Samsung is preparing to let users store a wider range of sensitive documents, including passports, national ID cards, driverâ€™s licenses, tax information, addresses, and more. The screenshots included in the leak show multiple new fields under categories like Personal documents, Private info, and Invoice info, complete with forms for name, DOB, gender, issuing authority, expiration, and even both sides of your ID card.

Unlike last time, the destinations menu is not blocking a portion of the map. Remember earlier this year when an update centered the map in Google Maps on Android Auto? Well, the app is starting to do it again. However, this time, users may find it to be a welcome change rather than an irksome update. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: 2026 needs to be the year Samsung fixes the Galaxy Z Flipâ€™s cover screen
items.summary: I want an app drawer and much, much more.
items.body: It sounds like Samsung has some pretty big plans for 2026 â€” thatâ€™s great. Iâ€™m excited by the idea of new cameras, a custom chipset, and renewed innovation in its foldable lineup. However, this all sounds like stuff weâ€™ve heard before. Weâ€™ve seen Samsung adopt a 200MP primary sensor, tack the For Galaxy badge onto Qualcommâ€™s latest chipset, and expand the Galaxy Z Flipâ€™s cover screen beyond its weird, folder-shaped limits. So, for any of these new promises to actually make an impact in 2026, I need just one thing out of Samsung: I need it to fix the Galaxy Z Flip 8â€™s cover screen. I know Iâ€™ve been asking for it for years, but hereâ€™s what needs to happen now.

items.title: New Play Store summaries save you from skimming app reviews
items.summary: Google's AI can tell you what the reviews say.
items.body: TL;DR AI-generated app review summaries are appearing on the Play Store. Googleâ€™s been working on this functionality for some time; we first saw signs it was coming last year. These summaries seem to be rolling out generally, but are not universally available yet. Generative AIâ€™s whole deal, when you boil it down, is absorbing existing information and then serving it up in other forms. That process can be wildly complex, as in the case of generative video â€” but on the simpler end of the spectrum, AI can be very helpful for parsing large bodies of text to create concise summaries. Googleâ€™s started putting its AI to work in the latter way on the Play Store, where youâ€™ll soon see AI-generated summaries of aggregated user app reviews. We were able to activate these AI-generated review summaries in the Play Store more than a year ago , but now, theyâ€™re starting to appear broadly, no fiddling required. Once these summaries have rolled out to your account, youâ€™ll see a bolded Users are saying heading in the Ratings and reviews section of Play Store app listings that have enough reviews to pull from. Each summary takes the form of a single paragraph that tries to highlight common positiveâ€¦

items.title: Why your cheap lens protector might be holding back your photos
items.summary: Cheap versus premium lens protectors: do you really get what you pay for?
items.body: Credit: Robert Triggs / Android Authority Protecting our expensive new smartphone is a top priority for many of us, and online marketplaces are flooded with options, from cases to display protection . An increasingly popular product segment is camera lens protectors, which obviously make a lot of sense if youâ€™ve just spent over $1,000 on one of the best camera phones on the market. While sticking a cheap layer of plastic or even glass in front of your high-precision camera might help protect it from scratches, thereâ€™s a risk that it will lower the quality of the pictures you take. Not necessarily because a protector will defocus or blur your images â€” something this close to the lens is unlikely to do that â€” but even a very transparent, high-quality protective layer will slightly reduce the amount of light reaching the sensor. In the worst case, introducing impure optics may exacerbate issues like edge aberration and lens flare, or reduce the amount of detail captured. Not what you want from a top-tier camera phone.

items.title: 5 apps I recommend you use instead of Google Calendar
items.summary: There are plenty of options, but to me, these 5 stand out.
items.body: The Day view with the bonus calendar above it. Credit: Andy Walker / Android Authority Donâ€™t get me wrong, thereâ€™s a lot to like about Google Calendar . Itâ€™s free, easy to use, and works seamlessly with the companyâ€™s other services, including Gmail, Drive, and Tasks . Itâ€™s even integrated with Gemini, so you can do things like prompt it to make a calendar entry. However, the app does have its downsides. It lacks any visual flair whatsoever, which is a common theme among Google apps. It doesnâ€™t support natural language processing, so you have to add in the date and time manually instead of just writing it out, like you can with most other tools these days. And the fact that itâ€™s owned by Google is a concern for some, since not everyone trusts their data with the tech giant .

items.title: YouTube Music on Wear OS shows signs of Material 3 Expressive revamp
items.summary: But, it looks like a job half-done!
items.body: Credit: Tushar Mehta / Android Authority TL;DR YouTube Music on Wear OS is getting new visual elements in line with Googleâ€™s Material 3 Expressive design. The redesign is live on the Wear OS tile as well as some other elements. However, the player interface is still using the older interface. Google has been working to bring its latest Material 3 Expressive aesthetics across multiple apps and interfaces. While Android phones have been the blessed recipients of the new design language, Google has also begun painting elements from the smaller screen with similar visuals. The Pixel Watch 4 is splattered with a healthy dose of the Expressive design, thanks to its Wear OS 6 interface . Meanwhile, Google has also been testing a design revamp for apps such as Maps , even on older versions of Wear OS. Apps, such as Google Calendar , Home, Keep, Messages , and Gemini for Watch , already have the updated visuals. Now, YouTube Music on Wear OS is getting a similar treatment.

items.title: I love uBlock, but itâ€™s not the first browser extension I install on my phone
items.summary: Control almost every aspect of web pages you visit on your phone.
items.body: As a committed Mozilla Firefox user on desktop and Android, I consistently install several extensions on my devices. uBlock Origin has a firm place on this list. This beloved content-blocking extension is like a digital pressure washer, blasting away content I donâ€™t want to see from the web pages I visit. Despite its usefulness, itâ€™s not the first browser extension I install on my personal device. That honor goes to one that packs the utility and extendibility of dozens of other extensions: a userscript manager called Violentmonkey. For the uninitiated, userscripts are small snippets of code, usually JavaScript, that can modify the functionality or appearance of a web page. Iâ€™ll admit that sounds pretty vague, but itâ€™s deliberately so. These scripts can accomplish a multitude of tasks, affect every site or specific pages, impact certain types of content, add or remove features, and even automate mundane tasks you encounter while browsing the web. Iâ€™ll run through a brief list of my favorite userscripts a little later, but for the purposes of this article, know that you canâ€™t just install userscripts directly to your browser â€” you need a userscript manager to handle them. This is wâ€¦

items.title: A lot of you are very upset with Googleâ€™s Material 3 Expressive design choices
items.summary: There's no pleasing everybody!
items.body: Good interface design â€” the kind thatâ€™s simultaneously intuitive, beautiful, responsive, and powerful â€” is just so deceptively tricky to get right. Sure, itâ€™s easy to complain about all the things we might not like about one particular UI, but thereâ€™s a big difference between being able to express some criticism and building something that everyoneâ€™s going to like. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: 5 changes the Galaxy S26 needs to win over frustrated fans
items.summary: Samsung has its work cut out for it with the Galaxy S26 series.
items.body: If youâ€™re a Samsung fan, chances are you werenâ€™t thrilled with this yearâ€™s Galaxy S25 series. Itâ€™s not that Samsungâ€™s S25 phones are bad, but theyâ€™re some of the most tepid year-over-year upgrades weâ€™ve ever seen. Samsungâ€™s hardware designs? Unchanged. Cameras? The same. Battery capacities and charging speeds? You already know the answer.

items.title: YouTube TV subscribers pay the price for its feud with Disney
items.summary: And all you might receive is a $20 credit.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR 20+ Disney-owned channels have been taken off YouTube TV after the two companies failed to renew licensing terms. The list includes several channels under ABC, ESPN, and Nat Geo labels, in addition to Disneyâ€™s. YouTube says it will refund subscribers $20 if the channels are off the network for too long. YouTube TV is already among the most expensive live digital TV services on offer in the US. And itâ€™s about to pinch its subscribers a little more as it has failed to renew its deal with Disney. Following a public spat from last week , when YouTube accused Disney of arm-twisting it, the two parties have failed to negotiate a mutually beneficial deal. With this, more than 20 channels from Disneyâ€™s network, including multiple ABC, ESPN, and National Geographic channels, have been removed from the live TV platform.

items.title: Pick your Women's World Cup team of the tournament
items.summary: As the Women's World Cup reaches the final, pick your team of your tournament.

items.title: Poll: Would you trade your TV for a Google TV projector?
items.summary: It could be time to give up the glow of your flat screen.
items.body: A TV is a staple in most households. Theyâ€™re substantial, predictable, and perfectly happy to broadcast your comfort sitcom to the same couch you make your way to every night. Lately, though, projectors have been making a play for the spotlight (literally). Impressive new models with Google TV baked in are turning heads and, in some cases, vying to replace your TV. From pocket-sized companions like the XGIMI MoGo 4 to living room workhorses like BenQâ€™s GV32, the projector market is starting to redirect from hobbyist to mainstream consumers. Where do you land?

items.title: 3 widgets I canâ€™t wait to try on Android Auto
items.summary: The potential to run a phone widget on my car screen is incredibly exciting.
items.body: Just this week, I was caught admiring the pretty features that CarPlay users are privy to, and Google mustâ€™ve grown jealous. Now it seems the company could be drawing inspiration from one of these for Android Auto . As uncovered by our exclusive reporting, Android Auto may soon get home screen widget support , opening up a selection of phone widgets for display on car dashboards. Unlike the CarPlay equivalent, the nascent feature â€” still codenamed â€œEarthâ€ â€” is very rough around the edges and has several limitations. In our tests, not every widget is supported, nor can you have more than one installed at any one time. Nevertheless, I can certainly see the potential, and as a fervent Android Auto user, Iâ€™m incredibly excited for whatâ€™s to come.

items.title: This leaked OnePlus flagship looks like a better bet than the OnePlus 15
items.summary: And could come with multiple upgrades over the current generation.
items.body: Credit: Aamir Siddiqui / Android Authority TL;DR OnePlusâ€™ next small phone just leaked, and it packs big upgrades. The OnePlus 15T is expected to feature a larger battery, an improved fingerprint scanner, and a new Snapdragon chipset. The sad part, though, is that OnePlus might not launch it in the US. The OnePlus 15 is peeking at us through the horizon. After launching in China this month , the phone is set to arrive globally next month with a mixed bag of upgrades and downgrades. Meanwhile, OnePlus is cooking another phone that could be all upgrades. Although it wonâ€™t arrive until next year, a leak has provided clarity about its tentative specifications. Leaker Digital Chat Station recently shared details about an upcoming small phone from OnePlus. Based on the screen size, we presume the leaker is discussing the successor to the OnePlus 13T, which launched globally as the OnePlus 13S . Therefore, it could be speculated to be called the OnePlus 15T or 15S, in line with the naming convention for the recently launched flagship.

items.title: Doomscrolling on the go? One UI 8.5 could help save your limited data plan (APK teardown)
items.summary: One UI 8.5's new "Adaptive Data Saver" will download social media videos only when you are ready to watch them.
items.body: Credit: Mishaal Rahman / Android Authority TL;DR Code within One UI 8.5 suggests Samsung could bring a new â€œAdaptive data saverâ€ feature to Galaxy phones. The feature works by only downloading videos in social media apps when you are â€œready to watch them.â€ This feature can help users with limited mobile data plans manage their social media data usage effectively. One UI 8.5 is expected to be a big update for Samsung Galaxy phones and tablets, in ways that One UI 8 wasnâ€™t. Weâ€™re expecting plenty of new features, ranging from Pro camera presets and sharing to Galaxy S26 Ultra exclusive features like Private Display , and more. Weâ€™ve now spotted another new feature in the works for One UI 8.5, and this one will likely be appreciated by people who donâ€™t have unlimited data access all the time. items.title: Has England's Euros triumph given women's club football a boost?
items.summary: One of the constant refrains throughout England's triumphant run at Euro 2025 â€“ and indeed most women's football matches in recent years â€“ has been how important the success of the Lionesses has been for the growth of the game. But what has been the impact?

items.title: Youâ€™re too old to get why Sam Altman just renamed ChatGPT 6 as â€˜GPT 6â€‘7â€™
items.summary: "6 7" has become the Word of the Year for 2025, and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is fully embracing the viral Gen Alpha slang.
items.body: Credit: ChatGPT TL;DR OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has said that the next version of ChatGPT, i.e., ChatGPT 6, will be renamed ChatGPT 6-7. While Altman may be joking, â€œ6 7â€ has actually been crowned as the Word of the Year 2025. In a perfectly timed post on X, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said that the next version of ChatGPT â€” ChatGPT 6 â€” will apparently be called â€œGPT 6-7.â€ If youâ€™re not a parent of a school-aged kid, you might be scratching your head right about now. But in the wonderfully bizarre times we live in, â€œ6 7â€ has officially been crowned Dictionary.comâ€™s Word of the Year 2025 .

items.title: US officials want to ban your Wi-Fi router for national security reasons
items.summary: Several US agencies have reportedly backed a proposal to impose a ban on the sale of TP-Link routers in the country.
items.body: Credit: Amazon TL;DR The Department of Commerce (DOC) has reportedly proposed a ban on the sales of TP-Link routers in the US. The proposal is reportedly backed by several federal agencies, including the Departments of Homeland Security, Justice, and Defense. The DOC is concerned that TP-Link routers pose a national security threat to the US, given the companyâ€™s Chinese origins. The US Department of Commerce (DOC) has floated a proposal against the sale and use of TP-Link products in the country, citing national security concerns.

items.title: Chromeâ€™s latest experiment could change how you start a search
items.summary: Chrome's new buttons point toward a future where browsing starts with AI, not typing.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR Chrome Canary is testing new â€œNano Bananaâ€ and â€œDeep Searchâ€ buttons that plug AI prompts directly into the search box. Nano Banana appears to cue image generation, while Deep Search suggests Gemini-powered research, with both currently requiring Chrome flags to enable. The features are unstable and do little right now, but they signal Googleâ€™s push to make Chrome more AI-driven. Google Chrome is testing two bold new buttons under its search box: Nano Banana and Deep Search. First spotted by Windows Report , the update appears in the Chrome Canary test build and looks like another step toward making Chrome a more AI-forward browser. These new chips sit just below the â€œAsk Googleâ€ field on a new tab page, alongside the existing AI Mode button that was added earlier this year .

items.title: Watch: Google and Magic Leap reveal fresh Android XR glasses prototype
items.summary: A renewed deal and a new demo hint at what Googleâ€™s XR future could look like.
items.body: Credit: Magic Leap TL;DR Google and Magic Leap showed a new Android XR glasses prototype at the FII event in Riyadh. The demo builds on earlier versions, such as Google Martha, showing Gemini identifying objects and offering real-time assistance. Magic Leap has extended its partnership with Google by three years and will act as an AR ecosystem partner, rather than a hardware maker. Itâ€™s only been a week since Samsung kicked off the Android XR era with its Galaxy XR headset , but Googleâ€™s already looking beyond bulky headsets to something much lighter. At the Future Investment Initiative (FII) event in Riyadh, Google and Magic Leap showed off a new Android XR glasses prototype â€” the first time weâ€™ve seen Google concept glasses on stage since I/O in the summer. As reported by Android Central , the two companies also confirmed theyâ€™ve extended their partnership for another three years. Magic Leap first teamed up with Google in 2024, combining its optics and manufacturing know-how with Googleâ€™s AI and display technology.

items.title: Google surprises Pixel users with another October update
items.summary: The Pixel 6 is missing out once again.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR Google has released new October builds for the Pixel line. The tech giant has yet to say what these builds are for. The update is available for the Pixel 7 and up. Google released the October 2025 update in the middle of the second week of the month. While it meant that we had to wait a few extra days, thatâ€™s not uncommon. Something a little less common is that the tech giant is now sending out another October build as we await the November 2025 update. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Nova Launcher gets surprise update following last monthâ€™s shutdown, but thereâ€™s a catch
items.summary: Nova Launcher rolls out an unexpected 8.1.3 update, but former developers say it is over a year old.
items.body: TL;DR Nova Launcher appeared to have shut down for good last month when its founder, Kevin Barry, left its parent company Branch Metrics. The launcher received a rare update on the Google Play Store today, its first since May 2024. The update includes new features and improved compatibility with newer Android versions, but its former developers say itâ€™s over a year old. Nova Launcher, the popular alternative Android launcher that appeared to shut down last month , is getting an unexpected update. The launcher was sold to analytics firm Branch Metrics in 2022, but by 2024, the company underwent mass developer layoffs. Only Nova Launcherâ€™s founder, Kevin Barry, remained working on the launcher until September 2025, when he too left Branch. Now, thereâ€™s a glimmer of hope Nova Launcher might not be completely dead yet. Nova Launcher users spotted an unexpected version 8.1.3 update roll out on the Google Play Store beta channel, according to a post on Redditâ€™s Nova Launcher sub from user colinaspinall . As of now, the latest update hasnâ€™t appeared through the stable release channel, or Nova Launcherâ€™s official beta website . While the update is a sign someone at Branch is paying attentâ€¦

items.title: Gboard is getting a new feature to help keep your GIF spam topical
items.summary: A new trending searches button is coming.
items.body: TL;DR Gboard is getting a button to browse trending GIF searches. These trending searches are apparently sourced from Tenor. The trending GIFs button isnâ€™t live in any user-facing version of Gboard yet. Gboard is making it easier to find GIFs about buzzy topics. Experimenting with the latest beta version of Googleâ€™s software keyboard, we managed to enable a new button that opens a list of trending GIF search terms. We saw this new trending topics button in Gboard version 16.3.2.821569955-beta-arm64-v8a beta. As it exists now, the button â€” a trend line pointing upward â€” appears near the search bar in the keyboardâ€™s GIF menu, next to the clock icon that opens your GIF history.

items.title: Itâ€™s official: Googleâ€™s Clock app is dropping support for non-Pixel smartwatches
items.summary: Google's Clock app is cutting off support for Samsung, OnePlus, and every other non-Pixel smartwatch.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR Users who own a Wear OS smartwatch will no longer be able to download Googleâ€™s Clock app. Non-Pixel smartwatches that have the app already installed will be able to continue using the software, but wonâ€™t receive updates. Pixel smartwatches will come with the app already installed and will receive updates. Last month, we reported that Galaxy Watch and OnePlus Watch owners were noticing something strange about Googleâ€™s Clock app. The software was no longer available to install on the Play Store. Meanwhile, those with the app already installed pointed out that the app description in the Play Store listing said that their device was not supported. At the time, it was unclear if this was a bug or a sign of an incoming change. It turns out that the answer was the latter. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Google Photos looks ready to finally solve its RAW backup problem
items.summary: Working with RAW images on Android could finally stop killing your cloud storage.
items.body: TL;DR Google Photos backs up RAW images alongside JPGs, which takes a lot of cloud storage. Earlier this year we found evidence for a new system that would store RAW images separately and not back them up. Weâ€™re now finally able to see this in action, and thereâ€™s even a toggle to opt in to backing up RAWs if youâ€™ve got the space. If you care even a little about photography, you probably know all about RAW images . While JPGs are convenient to post and share due to their relatively small file sizes, RAW files donâ€™t just capture an image without lots of lossy compression, but they store camera sensor data before things like white balance are corrected, giving you tons of power to control what your final output will look like, even with the photo already taken. Despite all that potential, though, theyâ€™re not without their problems, and weâ€™ve been keeping an eye on one in particular concerning how Android handles them. items.title: Cellebrite leak highlights how much more secure Pixel phones are with GrapheneOS
items.summary: Turns out one of the Pixelâ€™s best privacy upgrades doesnâ€™t come from Google at all.
items.body: Credit: Calvin Wankhede / Android Authority TL;DR A leaked Cellebrite chart shows Pixel phones running GrapheneOS largely resist the companyâ€™s forensic unlocking tools. The leak came from a private Google Teams call that someone joined and screenshotted before posting on a GrapheneOS forum. Pixel devices running standard Android still allow limited data access before first unlock, but GrapheneOS versions appear to block it more effectively. Google Pixel phones already have a solid reputation for security, but leaked Cellebrite documents show theyâ€™re even harder to crack when running GrapheneOS , the privacy-focused Android alternative. Cellebrite builds the forensic tools law enforcement uses to get data from locked phones. As reported by 404 Media , the leak came from someone who managed to join a private Microsoft Teams call between Cellebrite staff and a prospective customer. During the meeting, the uninvited participant took screenshots of what appears to be an internal â€˜Android OS Access Support Matrixâ€™ and then shared them on the GrapheneOS discussion forum .

items.title: Galaxy S22 phones in the US are getting their last major Android update
items.summary: No more pauses, please.
items.body: TL;DR Verizon support pages say that S22 series phones purchased from the carrier are now eligible to download One UI 8. Several comments on Reddit point to S22 phones also getting the update on AT&T. The rollout status of One UI 8 for unlocked S22 phones is unclear. One UI 8 has been making its way to Samsung phones in fits and starts for a few weeks now. The rollout has hit major milestone this week, with the Galaxy S22 series now receiving the update on multiple carriers in the US. Verizon has updated support pages for the Galaxy S22, S22+, and S22 Ultra to show that, starting today, each is eligible to download Android 16-based One UI 8 along with the October Android security patch. This comes after Samsung started and then paused One UI 8 distribution for international S22, S23, and S24 phones earlier this month.

items.title: AT&T is ready to go to court to defend its T-Mobile bashing ad
items.summary: The NAD ordered AT&T to remove promotional material that use its information last week.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR AT&T recently launched an ad campaign that uses the BBB National Programsâ€™ National Advertising Division findings to criticize T-Mobile for â€œun-truths.â€ The NAD has ordered AT&T to remove the promotional material, which it says violates ad-industry rules. The carrier has now filed a complaint for declaratory relief against the self-regulatory body. You may have caught the commercial by now, where AT&T uses Luke Wilson to talk about T-Mobile as a â€œmaster of breaking promises.â€ The commercial in question highlights the Un-Carrierâ€™s deceptive ads and other transgressions. Itâ€™s maybe one of the most direct attacks AT&T has taken against a rival in a long time. Now AT&T is fighting for the right to keep its campaign up. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Android 17 could bring full-screen apps to your phoneâ€™s always-on display
items.summary: Android 17 could introduce a new â€œMin Modeâ€ feature that lets apps display custom interfaces on the AOD.
items.body: TL;DR Google is developing a new â€œMin Modeâ€ feature for the Always-On Display that will allow apps to show their own minimal, persistent interfaces. This enables richer, glanceable experiences, with Google Maps expected to be one of the first apps to use it for low-power navigation. The feature uses the same ultra-low-power display state as AOD to save battery and will likely be introduced as a new developer API in Android 17. Most Android phones have an optional feature called always-on display (AOD) that, as its name implies, keeps your phoneâ€™s screen on at all times. This feature is handy because it lets you see the time and new notifications at a glance, though it does drain some extra battery. While Androidâ€™s new Live Updates feature lets you see more from certain notifications on the AOD, they can only show so much, forcing you to pick up your phone to get the full picture. To solve this problem, Google is working on a major evolution of the AOD in Android 17 that could allow apps to fully integrate with it. NEWSLETTER | Authority Insights --> Authority Insights You're reading an Authority Insights story. Subscribe to our new Authority Insights newsletter for more exclusive â€¦

items.title: This Android camera heavyweight raises the bar with 200MP telephoto and pro-grade video
items.summary: Pro-grade zoom meets MediaTek muscle, wrapped in vivoâ€™s biggest software refresh in years.
items.body: Credit: vivo TL;DR Vivo has launched the X300 and X300 Pro globally with new ZEISS-branded camera hardware and OriginOS 6. The X300 Pro is the higher-end model, offering a 200MP ZEISS APO telephoto camera and a larger battery. The X300 starts at â‚¬1,049 (~$1,215), while the X300 Pro will cost â‚¬1,399 (~$1,620) This yeah, vivo is marking its 30th anniversary with two new flagships, the X300 and X300 Pro, and the highlights are simple: 200MP ZEISS imaging across the board, plus a fresh global debut for OriginOS 6. The formula here isnâ€™t shock value; itâ€™s a focused push on photography, performance, and long-term software support that reads like a confident year-over-year step rather than a gamble. Both phones lean hard on ZEISS hardware and tuning, but they take different routes to get there. The X300 pairs a 200MP Ultra-Sensing HPB main camera with a 50MP ZEISS APO telephoto (LYT-602) and a 50MP ultrawide (JN1). The Pro flips things for telephoto fans, using a 200MP ZEISS APO telephoto as its centerpiece, backed by a 50MP â€œgimbal-gradeâ€ main camera (vivo Ã— Sony LYT-828, 1/1.28-inch) and a 50MP ultrawide. Both phones also upgrade the selfie system with a 50MP ZEISS wide-angle front camâ€¦

items.title: Deal: This Anker Prime Desktop Charger makes cable management a breeze
items.summary: Do you have a desk full of wires? Clean it up with this deal!
items.body: Credit: Anker via Amazon Donâ€™t you love those tidy desk setups you see online? I do too, but with so many devices, it is hard to handle cable management to that level. Hereâ€™s a way to minimize it. The Anker Prime Charger (200W, 6 Ports, GaN) is a desktop charger that minimizes clutter while saving you money, as it is currently 38% off. Buy the Anker Prime Charger with 200W, 6 Ports, GaN for just $49.99 ($30 off)

items.title: Retroid relaunches the Pocket 6 with a major twist â€” you pick the controls
items.summary: Retroid listened to fans and redesigned the Pocket 6 overnight, now giving you your choice of layouts.
items.body: Credit: X/@Retroid0fficial TL;DR Retroid has unveiled a redesigned Pocket 6 after backlash over the original layout. Buyers can now choose between D-pad-on-top or stick-on-top versions. The M1 and M2 buttons have moved to the back, with pre-orders reopening soon. Retroid isnâ€™t wasting any time fixing its most controversial product launch yet. Just a day after halting Pocket 6 pre-sales following fan criticism, the company has unveiled a redesigned version of the handheld. This time, itâ€™s giving players a choice. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: The Motorola Razr Ultra is my favorite flip phone, and itâ€™s $400 off
items.summary: Get the specced-out version at a price that competes with competitors' base models.
items.body: Credit: Ryan Haines / Android Authority If youâ€™re looking for an excellent foldable flip phone, you would have a hard time finding anything better than the Motorola Razr Ultra. In fact, many of us would agree that it beats the Samsung ones. The offering gets even sweeter with this deal, which cuts the price by a whopping $400. Buy the Motorola Razr Ultra with 1TB for just $1,099.99 ($400 off)

items.title: The Anker 320 Car Charger is a mere $7.99 right now!
items.summary: That's about the price of a cup of coffee!
items.body: Credit: Anker via Amazon Do you often find yourself running out of battery? Studies say the average American spends about an hour a day driving . Why not optimize that time and turn it into more charging time? Hereâ€™s a great deal for you: The Anker 320 Car Charger is now on sale for just $7.99! Buy the Anker 320 Car Charger for just $7.99 ($5 off)

items.title: Anker NEBULA Capsule 3 Projector plummets to new all-time low price!
items.summary: This projector is tiny, super portable, and convenient. You can use it anywhere!
items.body: Credit: Anker via Amazon My life has changed since I got a projector. Movie nights have become magical, and you can join the fun without paying full price, thanks to this Anker NEBULA Capsule 3 Projector deal. Itâ€™s the cheapest it has ever been, saving you $190. Buy the Anker NEBULA Capsule 3 Projector for just $339.99 ($190 off)

items.title: Record-low deal: Save $100 on the BLUETTI Elite 30 V2 Power Station
items.summary: This is about the funnest power station I've seen!
items.body: Credit: BLUETTI via Amazon Power stations are capable, functional, super convenient, and very functional. That said, they are very rarely playful or fun. Why not also make them personal? BLUETTI is starting the trend with the BLUETTI Elite 30 V2 Portable Power Station. Itâ€™s fun, portable, colorful, and currently $100 off! Buy the BLUETTI Elite 30 V2 Portable Power Station for just $199 ($100 off)

items.title: How Android handles Hi-Res audio: An audiophileâ€™s guide to the best sound
items.summary: Your smartphone might be the best music player you already own.
items.body: Credit: Tushar Mehta / Android Authority While thereâ€™s been a modest revival in dedicated audio players, most listeners â€” including many discerning audiophiles â€” are streaming music straight from their smartphones. And why not? Android devices offer a vast selection of music streaming platforms , surprisingly capable speakers, and some of the best Bluetooth connectivity around. Still, Androidâ€™s audio signal chain remains a bit of a black box. What actually happens to your music between the app and your headphone driver is often unclear. To lift the veil, hereâ€™s how Android handles your audio â€” and what you can do to get the best possible sound.

items.title: A crucial data analysis feature is coming to NotebookLM very soon
items.summary: Along with the possibility to generate podcasts from your financial statements, because why not?
items.body: Credit: Andy Walker / Android Authority TL;DR Google has confirmed it is bringing Sheets support to NotebookLM â€œvery soon.â€ This complements Docs and Slides support in NotebookLM. Sheets support is currently limited to NotebookLM Plus users, i.e., those who subscribe to Googleâ€™s AI Plus or AI Pro plans. NotebookLM is easily one of Googleâ€™s most highly cherished AI tools , with fewer haters than any other of Googleâ€™s apps. It lets you research and process data from numerous different sources and convert verbose formats into digestible chunks, or even AI-generated podcasts and video essays. With an upcoming update, Google is set to improve file support for free users. Google Drive integration already lets you import files from Docs and Slides as sources to NotebookLM. But the research tool lacks support for Google Sheets (or .XLS and .XLSX files) in the free tier. Thankfully, if youâ€™ve been yearning for the option to import your Sheets or Excel files to NotebookLM, Google may be bringing it to you soon.

items.title: I love Gmail, but it desperately needs these upgrades
items.summary: Make it happen, Google.
items.body: Credit: Andy Walker / Android Authority Iâ€™ve been a Gmail user for as long as I can remember, which is evident by the 1,607 unread emails that are currently in my account. And while I donâ€™t blame Google for my lack of email organizational skills â€” although this was never an issue when Inbox was around â€” I still feel like the company could drastically improve the service with just a few simple tweaks. My main issue is with the Android app , although most of my suggestions also apply to the web version. Hereâ€™s what I think the tech giant should change and why.

items.title: T-Mobile is switching up how it handles payment arrangements
items.summary: T-Mobile now limits payment arrangements to the T-Life app, dropping in-store and phone options.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR Starting today, T-Mobile will only allow payment arrangements through the T-Life app. In-store and customer support call options previously required a fee, but have now been discontinued entirely. The move continues T-Mobileâ€™s shift away from traditional customer service channels as it consolidates all its functionality under the T-Life app. In the current economy, itâ€™s easy to fall behind on your bills from time to time. The good news is that many utilities offer payment arrangements to help you pay off your overdue balance gradually, including cellular companies like T-Mobile . While youâ€™ll still technically be overdue and subject to extra fees, an arrangement ensures your account wonâ€™t be suspended while you work to bring your payment history up to date. For the Un-carrier, there have always been three ways to do this: via the app, in-store, or through a customer support call. According to a new report from The Mobile Report , all but one of these options is going away.

items.title: Spec leak for this Nintendo DS clone reveals exactly why it comes in at under $100
items.summary: The first affordable two-screen emulation handheld makes some major concessions.
items.body: TL;DR Specs for ANBERNICâ€™s upcoming RG DS have leaked via an AliExpress listing. It will have two 4-inch 640Ã—480 screens and a Rockchip RK3568 SoC. Those screens wonâ€™t integer scale DS games, and the SoC is too weak for the MelonDS emulator. The dual-screen gaming handheld race already has two premium champions in the AYANEO Pocket DS and AYN Thor , but ANBERNICâ€™s more budget-friendly RG DS made big waves when it was announced earlier this month . Coming in at under $100, it was always the case that some concessions would need to be made. but a recent spec leak has dampened some of the communityâ€™s excitement. A listing from ANBERNICâ€™s AliExpress storefront was published online, and although itâ€™s since been pulled, it revealed the full specs, size, and more. Starting with the screens, it will feature two 4-inch IPS screens with a resolution of 640Ã—480. Thatâ€™s a fairly limited resolution for screens this size, but the real issue is that it doesnâ€™t support perfect integer scaling for DS games. Instead, itâ€™s 2.5x, which can lead to some wonky visuals, especially in pixel art games.

items.title: Youâ€™re missing out on your Pixel 10â€™s best camera feature
items.summary: Don't sleep on the new and improved panorama mode!
items.body: Credit: Rita El Khoury / Android Authority When Google announced the Pixel 10 series , a lot of focus was given to the new 100x Pro Res Zoom as the highlight camera feature, with Camera Coach taking the second seat. What went under the radar is Googleâ€™s continuous work on Panorama mode, which today is absolutely amazing and has finally reached its full potential. Iâ€™ve been using my Pixel 10 Pro XL as my main camera for a couple of months, including a short trip to Athens and some sightseeing around France while my parents were visiting. Hereâ€™s what makes panorama mode amazing on this phone and why I think people are sleeping on it.

items.title: Details about Qualcommâ€™s non-flagship flagship chipset emerge in new leak
items.summary: Qualcomm's upcoming Snapdragon 8 Gen 5 (non-Elite) looks like a mix bag of upgrades and downgrades.
items.body: TL;DR Details about Qualcommâ€™s upcoming Snapdragon 8 Gen 5 (non-Elite variant) have leaked. The chipset is expected to be built on TSMCâ€™s newer N3P fabrication process, which is also used for the Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5. It follows a similar design to the Snapdragon 8 Elite chips, including Qualcommâ€™s custom Oryon cores, but with a lower clock speed than the Elite Gen 5. In addition to launching the top-tier Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5 earlier than usual this year, Qualcomm also confirmed it is working on the non-Elite variant of the chipset. The standard Snapdragon 8 Gen 5 has yet to hit the market, but Qualcomm has already shared some specifics about the chipset, including a vague description of the CPU. Now, a recent leak is plugging any previous gap in information with more details. Leaker Digital Chat Station recently shared specifications for the Snapdragon 8 Gen 5, including its CPU and GPU . Per the leak, the chipset is set to be fabricated on TSMCâ€™s N3P 3nn process, identical to the Elite edition. This is TSMCâ€™s third-gen 3nm process, which offers marginal gains in performance and efficiency over the N3E process that was utilized for the Snapdragon 8 Elite from last year.

items.title: Iâ€™m a OnePlus fan, but the OnePlus 15 broke my heart
items.summary: This isn't the OnePlus phone I was hoping for.
items.body: Iâ€™m a big fan of OnePlus phones. From the day I got my invite to buy the OnePlus One to happily using the OnePlus 13 for much of 2025, OnePlusâ€™s Android handsets have really resonated with me over the years. The companyâ€™s focus on smooth performance, long battery life, fast charging, unique hardware, and opinionated cameras are all things I value in an Android phone, and OnePlus has consistently delivered on them. And yet, with the OnePlus 15 , I find myself feeling rather conflicted. OnePlus did a lot right with the phone, and its commitment to performance, battery, and charging is more evident than ever. But at the same time, OnePlus sacrificed other parts of its identity to the point where Iâ€™m not even sure I recognize this as a OnePlus phone.

items.title: Google Maps is working on an extremely minimalist power saving mode
items.summary: Don't leave me stranded with no idea of where I'm going!
items.body: TL;DR Google Maps appears to be working on a new power saving mode for navigation. The mode would eliminate almost all UI elements and extraneous map labeling from your view. Power saving mode limitations could prevent it from working in landscape or with public transit. When is the absolute worst time for your phone to be running low on battery ? Halfway through filming your kidâ€™s play? First thing in the morning when you realize you forgot to charge it overnight? While we could keep going for pretty much ever, high on that list would absolutely be â€œwhen youâ€™re in the middle of navigating somewhere.â€ Thankfully, Google Maps could soon offer a new mode for dealing with exactly those kind of emergencies.
